scenario_name: Azure Cognitive Search Relevance Boost Squad Mission (8‑week cycle)
company_context: Microsoft – Azure Cloud division – Azure Cognitive Search product team. The squad operates under the MMM (Mission‑Milestones‑Metrics) framework and reports to the Azure AI & Search Platform group. The squad’s charter is to embed next‑gen AI ranking into the Azure Search service to increase enterprise adoption and drive Azure revenue growth.
meeting_event_details: Squad Mission Planning Meeting – 2025‑09‑02, 10:00 AM PST (UTC‑08:00), 90 minutes, Microsoft Teams (meeting link: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/meetup‑join/...). Attendees: all squad members and the Azure Search Platform PMO. The meeting will be recorded and minutes posted to the squad’s SharePoint site.
stakeholders: Priya Patel – Senior Product Manager (DRI – Directly Responsible Individual)
Alex Chen – Engineering Lead (Principal Software Engineer, Search Core)
Maya Singh – Data Science Lead (Senior Data Scientist, Ranking Models)
Luis Gomez – UX Lead (Principal Designer, Search UI/UX)
Ravi Kumar – QA Lead (Senior Test Engineer)
Jenna Lee – Program Manager, Azure AI Platform (dependency manager)
Tom O'Connor – Finance Business Partner (budget oversight)
Sofia Alvarez – Compliance Officer (GDPR & data‑privacy)
Mike Reynolds – VP, Azure AI & Search (executive sponsor)
deliverables: 1. Data ingestion pipeline for click‑through and relevance feedback (Azure Data Factory + Synapse).
2. Baseline relevance benchmark suite (NDCG@10, MAP) on the public MS MARCO dataset and internal enterprise logs.
3. Prototype AI‑reranking model (Transformer‑based) trained in Azure ML v2, with reproducible notebooks.
4. API extension – `/search/v2/rerank` endpoint with Swagger spec and integration tests.
5. UI mock‑ups and interactive prototype for the Azure Portal search results page (Figma files).
6. Automated test suite (unit, integration, performance) achieving ≥95 % code coverage.
7. Beta rollout package (Helm chart, deployment scripts) for Azure Marketplace customers.
8. Final release documentation, migration guide, and internal training deck.
9. Post‑release performance report (metrics vs. baseline, latency, cost analysis).
success_criteria: • ≥15 % lift in NDCG@10 on the enterprise query set versus the current BM25 baseline.
• ≤10 % increase in 99th‑percentile query latency (target ≤200 ms additional latency).
• ≥80 % of beta customers report “Improved relevance” in the post‑beta survey (minimum 30 responses).
• ≥95 % automated test coverage across new code paths.
• Release on schedule (Week 8) within the allocated $250 k budget.
• No GDPR compliance violations; all data used is anonymized per policy.
• Demonstrated cost‑per‑query increase ≤5 % relative to baseline.
constraints: Budget: $250,000 total (cloud compute, contractor hours, licensing).
Compute: Limited to 200 GPU‑hours per week on Azure ML due to shared quota.
Dependencies: Must integrate with Azure ML v2 pipeline (release scheduled for T‑48) and the upcoming Azure Search SDK v3 (target GA at T‑50).
Compliance: All training data must be GDPR‑scrubbed; privacy review required before model export.
Resource availability: Two senior engineers (Alex & Priya) will be on the Azure AI Platform migration project during Weeks 5‑6, reducing capacity.
External stakeholder sign‑off: Beta customers must approve the test plan by Week 3.
workback_prompt: Generate a detailed work‑back plan for the 'Azure Cognitive Search Relevance Boost Squad Mission' (8‑week cycle) using the MMM framework. Include weekly tasks, owners, dependencies, risk mitigations, and required artifacts for each milestone (Weeks 2, 4, 6, 8). Align the plan with the success criteria, constraints, and the company’s AI‑first Azure strategy. Output the plan in a tabular format (Week, Milestone, Deliverable, Owner, Dependencies, Risks, Mitigation).

scenario_name: VisionEdge Squad – Real‑Time Object Detection API Launch (8‑week mission)
company_context: Microsoft Azure – Azure AI Vision team. The VisionEdge Squad (6‑8 members) is part of the Azure AI platform, operating under the MMM (Mission‑Metrics‑Milestones) framework. Mission statement: “Deliver a low‑latency, high‑accuracy real‑time object‑detection API for edge devices that expands Azure AI’s edge portfolio and drives 5,000 new developer sign‑ups in the first month.” Duration: 8 weeks (T‑56 to T‑0). DRI: Priya Patel (Senior Program Manager, Azure AI Vision). Squad members: Alex Chen (Lead Software Engineer), Maya Singh (Data Scientist), Luis Gomez (UX Designer), Fatima Al‑Mansour (Cloud Infrastructure Engineer), Jenna Lee (QA Lead), Raj Patel (Partner Engineer – Azure IoT Hub). Cross‑functional roles include PM, Software Engineers, Cloud Engineers, UX, Data Science, QA, and Partner Engineering. Key milestones every 2 weeks: • Week 2 (T‑42): Requirements freeze & design sign‑off • Week 4 (T‑28): MVP prototype & internal demo • Week 6 (T‑14): Beta release to 20 pilot customers • Week 8 (T‑0): General Availability launch with full SDKs and launch marketing pack. Success metrics (quantitative): • End‑to‑end inference latency ≤ 30 ms on Azure Edge VM • Model mAP ≥ 92 % on Edge‑device benchmark set • Cost per inference ≤ $0.001 • 5,000+ active developer accounts within 30 days of GA • NPS ≥ 70 from beta participants. The mission directly supports Microsoft’s FY25 strategy to grow Azure AI revenue by 15 % and to lead the edge‑computing market while meeting sustainability targets (≤ 0.5 kg CO₂ per 1 M inferences).
meeting_event_details: Squad Mission Planning Meeting – Monday, 09 Sep 2025, 10:00 AM – 11:30 AM PST (90 min). Location: Microsoft Teams (primary) + Azure West Conference Room 3B (secondary for in‑person attendees). Agenda: review mission statement, confirm milestones, assign owners, surface dependencies, and capture success metrics.
stakeholders: Priya Patel – Senior Program Manager (DRI) – owns overall mission success, timeline, and stakeholder alignment.
Alex Chen – Lead Software Engineer – responsible for API design, implementation, and performance tuning.
Maya Singh – Data Scientist – builds and validates the object‑detection model, defines accuracy metrics.
Luis Gomez – UX Designer – creates developer portal UI/UX, documentation layout, and onboarding flow.
Fatima Al‑Mansour – Cloud Infrastructure Engineer – provisions Edge VM scale‑sets, ensures cost targets.
Jenna Lee – QA Lead – defines test plan, runs automated & manual validation, signs off release quality.
Raj Patel – Partner Engineer (Azure IoT Hub) – coordinates dependency on IoT Hub SDK v3.2 release.
Ellen Zhou – Marketing Program Manager – prepares launch communications, blog, and dev‑community outreach.
deliverables: VisionEdge API Specification (v1.0) – functional and non‑functional requirements document.
Edge‑optimized object‑detection model (ONNX format) with training pipeline scripts.
C# and Python SDKs (v1.0) with sample code and CI/CD pipelines.
Developer portal UI mockups and final responsive web pages.
Performance benchmark report (latency, accuracy, cost) against Azure Edge VM SKUs.
Beta test report – feedback summary, NPS score, and defect backlog.
GA launch package – release notes, migration guide, marketing assets, and internal rollout checklist.
success_criteria: Latency ≤ 30 ms measured on Azure Edge VM Standard_E2s_v3 under 100 concurrent requests.
Mean Average Precision (mAP) ≥ 92 % on the EdgeBench validation set.
Cost per inference ≤ $0.001 when run at 1 M inferences per day.
≥ 5,000 unique developer accounts created and at least 1,000 active daily users within 30 days of GA.
Net Promoter Score (NPS) ≥ 70 from the beta cohort of 20 pilot customers.
Zero critical defects (Severity‑1) at GA release; all Severity‑2 defects resolved before launch.
Launch marketing campaign reaches ≥ 200,000 impressions and generates ≥ 2,000 click‑throughs to the developer portal.
constraints: Total mission budget capped at $500,000 (including cloud consumption, contractor licenses, and marketing spend).
Must comply with GDPR and Microsoft Responsible AI standards – model documentation and data handling reviewed by Legal/Risk by Week 4.
Dependency on Azure IoT Hub SDK v3.2 (scheduled release T‑30); any delay pushes MVP prototype deadline.
Only two full‑time software engineers (Alex Chen + a contractor) allocated due to concurrent Azure Synapse project.
Launch must occur before the end of FY25 Q4 (31 Oct 2025) to count toward Azure AI revenue targets.
All code must pass Microsoft Secure Development Lifecycle (SDL) checks before GA.
workback_prompt: Generate a detailed workback plan for the VisionEdge Squad mission to launch the real‑time object detection API for edge devices. Include all milestones (T‑56, T‑42, T‑28, T‑14, T‑0), weekly tasks, owners, dependencies (e.g., Azure IoT Hub SDK v3.2), resource allocations, risk mitigation, and deliverable dates. Align each task with the success metrics and constraints listed, and format the plan as a Gantt‑style table with clear start/end dates, effort estimates, and required approvals.

scenario_name: Project Aurora – AI‑Powered Search Optimization Squad Mission
company_context: Microsoft Azure AI division, Cloud Search product team. The squad is part of the Azure Cognitive Search group, tasked with integrating a new large‑language‑model (LLM) based relevance engine into the existing search service. The team follows the MMM (Mission‑Milestone‑Metric) framework and operates as a cross‑functional, autonomous squad of 7 members.
meeting_event_details: 2025-12-02, 10:00 AM – 11:00 AM PST, 60‑minute virtual kickoff via Microsoft Teams (Meeting ID: 274 819 562). All squad members and key stakeholders are required to attend.
stakeholders: Priya Patel – Directly Responsible Individual (DRI), Senior Product Manager – owns mission success, defines scope, and prioritizes backlog.
Liam O'Connor – Engineering Lead, Senior Software Engineer – responsible for architecture, code quality, and delivery of the LLM inference service.
Aisha Rahman – UX Lead, Interaction Designer – designs UI/UX for the new relevance controls and admin dashboards.
Dr. Chen Wu – Data Science Lead, Principal Data Scientist – builds and validates the LLM relevance model, defines evaluation metrics.
Ravi Kumar – Security & Compliance Engineer – ensures the solution meets Azure security baselines and GDPR/CCPA requirements.
Megan Liu – Marketing & Go‑to‑Market Manager – creates launch messaging, beta program plan, and adoption tracking.
Jenna Torres – Program Manager, Azure Cloud Infra – coordinates dependencies on compute quota, networking, and storage provisioning.
deliverables: Mission Charter (incl. scope, success metrics, risk register) – due T+2 weeks.
Technical Architecture Document and API spec for the LLM relevance service – due T+2 weeks.
High‑fidelity UI mockups and interaction flow for relevance controls – due T+4 weeks.
Prototype LLM model trained on Azure Search logs with baseline relevance score – due T+4 weeks.
Beta‑ready integrated service (CI/CD pipeline, automated tests, security hardening) deployed to Azure staging – due T+6 weeks.
Beta program plan, pilot customer list, and success measurement framework – due T+6 weeks.
General Availability (GA) release package: code, documentation, rollout checklist, and post‑launch monitoring dashboard – due T+8 weeks.
success_criteria: Achieve ≥20 % reduction in average query latency for relevance‑enhanced searches in the beta environment.
Increase relevance‑score (NDCG@10) by ≥15 % compared with the existing BM25 baseline on a held‑out test set.
Onboard at least 5 strategic enterprise customers into the beta program within 2 weeks of beta launch.
Maintain 99.9 % availability of the LLM inference endpoint during the beta period.
Pass all Azure security compliance scans (Microsoft Secure Development Lifecycle) with zero critical findings.
Deliver GA on schedule (T+8 weeks) within the allocated $250k budget.
Post‑launch adoption: ≥30 % of Azure Search customers enable the new relevance feature within 30 days of GA.
constraints: Total budget capped at $250,000 (includes cloud compute, third‑party model licensing, and contractor UX work).
Compute quota for GPU‑accelerated VMs must be secured from the Cloud Infra team by T+1 week.
All data used for model training must be anonymized and stored in a compliant Azure Blob container (RG‑azsearch‑ml).
Dependency on the Azure Identity team for token‑based authentication integration – delivery expected by T+3 weeks.
Legal review of the external model licensing agreement must be completed before any production deployment (deadline T+5 weeks).
Team members are allocated 75 % of their time to this mission; other commitments must not exceed 25 %.
workback_prompt: Generate a detailed 8‑week workback plan for the 'Project Aurora – AI‑Powered Search Optimization' squad mission. Include bi‑weekly milestones, owners, required inputs/outputs for each milestone, risk mitigation actions, and a timeline view. Align each deliverable and success metric with the mission charter, and reference the constraints (budget, compute quota, legal review, and cross‑team dependencies). Use the MMM framework (Mission, Milestone, Metric) to structure the plan and provide a concise executive summary for senior leadership.
